claim.hypotheses: The Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect (BFLPE) will be observable for mathematics self-concept across all 16 student characteristics examined; any moderating effects of academic self-regulation and socioeconomic status (SES) will be statistically significant but practically small.
claim.hypotheses_location: Introduction / Present Study section – discussion of research aims and the 16 proposed moderators (pages 4-6 of the PDF).
claim.statement: Analyses of the 2003 PISA data show that the Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect is highly robust: school-average ability is a substantial negative predictor of students’ mathematics self-concept, and this effect generalises across student characteristics with only small moderating influences from academic self-regulation and socioeconomic status.
claim.statement_location: Abstract and Conclusion sections (pages 2 and 38-40 of the PDF).

data.source: Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) 2003 student survey and achievement database
data.sample_size: 265,180 students nested in 10,221 schools across 41 countries
data.access_details: Publicly available from the OECD upon registration; downloadable SPSS/SAS data files with accompanying manual.
data.notes: Five plausible values for mathematics ability used; weighted analyses; large-scale complex sampling design.

method.description: The study employed three-level hierarchical linear modelling to estimate the impact of school-average mathematics ability on individual students’ mathematics self-concept and to test interactions with 16 putative moderators (e.g., SES indices, motivation, learning strategies, anxiety). Analyses were run separately for each plausible value of math ability and then averaged.
steps: Download PISA 2003 student-level and school-level data files.
Merge necessary student, school and country identifiers; apply OECD sampling weights.
Compute outcome variable: mathematics self-concept (4-item Likert scale, Cronbach’s α = .88).
Compute key predictors: school-average mathematics ability, individual mathematics ability (linear and quadratic), 16 moderator indices (standardised).
Specify three-level multilevel regression model (student, school, country).
Run model five times using each plausible value for math ability without averaging them beforehand.
Average the resulting coefficients across the five runs.
Evaluate significance with p < .001 threshold; calculate standardised effect sizes comparable to Cohen’s d.
method.models: Three-level hierarchical linear regression models with fixed and random effects; interaction terms between school-average ability and each moderator.
method.control_variables: Individual mathematics ability (linear and quadratic terms), OECD sampling weights; country-level random intercepts.

results.summary: School-average mathematics ability exerted a substantial negative effect on students’ mathematics self-concept (confirming the BFLPE). The coefficient was −0.319 (effect size −0.520). While interactions involving academic self-regulation (e.g., self-efficacy) and SES reached statistical significance, their practical impact was negligible, demonstrating the robustness and generalisability of the BFLPE across the 16 student characteristics examined.
